1 Introduction

2 International Finance as a Regime Complex

Similarly to other domains that have been covered more extensively by the literature on international regime complexity, the presence of multiple institutions involved in setting and monitoring international financial standards is one of the defining features of the international financial regulatory architecture.

A patchwork of often informal and opaque international financial standard-setting bodies has emerged in ad hoc way in the post-Bretton Woods era (Porter 2005a; Mügge and Perry 2014; C. Randall Henning and Pratt 2021; Newman and Posner 2018). For instance, the failure of Bankhaus Herstatt in West Germany in 1974 led the central bank Governors of the Group of Ten countries to coordinate their international response and to establish the Committee of Banking Regulations and Supervisory Practices, subsequently renamed as Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (Kapstein 1989; Goodhart 2011). The challenges associated with the greater international integration of securities and insurance markets led securities regulators of major industrialized and developing countries to the creation of what came to be known as International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) (Underhill 1995). Along the same lines, national insurance regulators come together in 1994 to form the International Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS) (Singer 2007).

Over the years, a rich body of scholarship has investigated how the process of international standard-setting in finance is influenced by different elements of these bodies, such as as their network-like structure (Slaughter 2004; Porter 2005a), the soft-law nature of their regulatory agreements (Zaring (1998); Brummer (2014); Newman and Posner (2016)), the highly technical nature of their work (Porter 2003), the ideas and common normative frameworks informing the work of transnational regulatory process (Kapstein 1992; Seabrooke and Tsingou 2014; Ban, Seabrooke, and Freitas 2016), the limited transparency and exclusionary institutional process that inform the work of transgovernmental regulatory agencies (Underhill and Zhang 2008), as well as the access points that this provides of different groups in the regulatory process (Lall 2012; Tsingou 2015).

While focusing on different elements and characteristics of the existing international financial bodies, most of the existing analysis share a common focus on looking primarily at individual institutions in isolation from the work of other bodies. This is understandable as most of these international financial organizations have largely emerged independently from one another along sectoral lines and focused on separate areas of financial governance.

Over the years, however, the fragmented nature of international financial architecture has come under scrutiny from different fronts. Various scholars and policymakers have noted that the progressively greater integration of different financial markets limited the capacity of the existing sectorally-differentiated to identify and tackle new financial vulnerabilities emerging across the purview of different institutions.(Tietmeyer 1999; Porter 2005b; Mügge and Perry 2014). For instance, while in areas such as commercial banks a go-to institution emerged since the early stages, no single international standard-setting institution emerged in the area of derivatives markets (Helleiner, Pagliari, and Spagna 2018; Quaglia and Spendzharova 2021).

Moreover, the capacity of different international institutions to achieve their objective has come to be affected by standards set elsewhere. For instance, the calculation of the bank capital requirements set by the BCBCs remains influenced by the international accounting standards set by the International Accounting Standards Board. Uncoordinated policy changes across the two institutions have been presented as producing unintended negative externalities in the regulation of the banking industry (Becker and Linder 2021; Mügge and Perry 2014).

In light of these challenges, different initiatives have emerged over the years to facilitate greater coordination among different sectoral standard-setting bodies. An important trigger for this move was the emerging market crises of the 1990s such as the Mexican crisis of 1994 and the East Asian crisis of 1997-98. In 1996 the Joint Forum was created to bring together banking (BCBS), securities (IOSCO) and insurance (IAIS) standard setters in order to develop principles that would affect all three sectors.

In 1999, a new body called the Financial Stability Forum (FSF) was created to bring bring together not only the sectoral standard-setter such as IOSCO, IAIS, and BCBS, but also other treaty-based international financial organizations such the OECD, the IMF, and the World Bank, (Walter 2008; Moschella 2012).

Around the same time, also the engagement between the IMF and World Bank became progressively more institutionalised (Kranke 2020). In the 1990s the IMF and World Bank have developed the Financial Sector Assessment Programme (FSAP); and the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative, which was later ‘enhanced’ through Poverty Reduction Strategy Papers (PRSPs).1

In addition to these steps to increase the coordination among bodies, new initiatives have also emerged to make the regime more hierarchical.

In particular, the transformation of the Financial Stability Forum into the Financial Stability Board (FSB) in 2009 coincided with a formalization of the mandate of this institution to “promote and help coordinate the alignment of the activities” of international standard setters and to “undertake joint strategic reviews” of their work to ensure it was “timely, coordinated, focused on priorities and addressing gaps,” while respecting other bodies’ mandates and independence. The Financial Stability Board has been described as having emerged a “hub intermediary” (Quaglia and Spendzharova 2021) and “peak body” (Walter 2019) within the international regulatory architecture. For instance Quaglia and Spendzharova (2021) discuss the contribution that the FSB played in fostering a division of labour and overall progress in the setting of standards concerning the regulation of derivatives markets.

Moreover, an important hierarchical dimension in the regime has emerged as the result of the involvement of apex policy forum (Baker 2010) such as the G7/8 first and the G20 later, which have occasionally taken a more active role in steering the activities of transgovernmental regulatory networks. At the first summit of the G20 Finance Minister in 1999, the summit identified its “comparative advantage” in “encouraging the implementation of measures, which had been developed by other international bodies, such as the IMF, the World Bank, or other international forums, but had yet to be widely adopted” (G20 1999, cited by Viola 2015).

However, in recent years, different scholars havet theorized how G20 leaders and finance ministers have played a greater role in swaying the agenda of technocratic standard setting bodies (Baker and Carey 2014). For instance Baker and Carey (2014, 99) argue that “the G20 approved and legitimised efforts to make regulation more ‘macroprudential’ and thus set in train a whole industry of research and knowledge generation in specialist international technical”. The role of the G20 in international financial governance has been described as resembling that of an “orchestrator” (Quaglia and Spendzharova 2021; Viola 2015), deploying different strategies to direct the work of other bodies. These included its “power of instigation” to set broad agendas and priorities for the wider institutional complex of international financial governance” (Baker and Carey 2014, 92), but also “power of endorsement” (Baker and Carey 2014) to approve of the findings of more specialist networks and bodies (see also Viola 2015; Eccleston, Kellow, and Carroll 2015; Büttner and Thiemann 2017).

While these authors have ascribed a pivotal and transformative role to the direct involvement of the G7/G20 and the FSB in the international financial regulatory regimes, others works point to the fact that the capacity of bodies such as the FSB and G20 bodies to influence the work of other institutions is hindered by the lack of clear accountability mechanisms between international financial institutions and these coordinating bodies,” (Helleiner 2014; Viola 2015, 95), the independence of standard-setting bodies which are not “directly empowered by or accountable to the G20 (Viola 2015 ) Moreover, Newman and Posner (2018) claim that the soft-law nature of the standards produced by international financial institutions limits the capacity”to impose a hierarchical structure over the field of specialized standard setters”.

3 Method

3.1 Existing approaches

While the international financial regime has become over the years populated by a larger number of key institutions engaged in the role of setting standards and policies, the extent to which this regime complex has become more integrated or hierarchical has not been systematically explored. Most of the analyses that have explored the role of international financial institutions have historically focused on the work of individual standard-setting bodies and generalized from there.

In recent years, different works have drawn upon the literature on regime complexity body of theory to understand the evolution in this domain (Heldt and Schmidtke 2019; Breen, Hodson, and Moschella 2020; C. Randall Henning 2017; Quaglia and Spendzharova 2021; Zhang 2021). However, also these works have primarily focused on the interaction between two or few more institutions analyzed through in-depth case studies, such as the relationship between BCBS and IASB (Mügge and Perry 2014; Becker and Linder 2021); BCBS and IOSCO (Mügge and Perry 2014); IMF and World Bank (Kranke 2020); or between the G20 and standard-setting bodies (Viola 2015; Quaglia and Spendzharova 2021).

This methodological emphasis is not unique to the study of the international financial architecture. As different authors have noted (Haftel and Lenz 2021; Ahlström and Cornell 2018; Jessica F. Green 2013; Zürn, Kreuder-Sonnen, and Fuß 2021), scholarship on regime complex has primarily focused on rich description of individual case studies and analyzing the impact of regime complexity in a small number of intergovernmental agreements.

As the number of institutions involved in a given area increase, however, this methodological emphasis on in-depth analysis of selected institutions limits the extent to which general dynamics of inter-organizational interaction in global politics can be assessed across time and different bodies (Sommerer and Tallberg 2019: 400; Haftel and Lenz 2021). Specifically, as the number of international bodies that populate a given regime grows, analyses aimed to produce inferences about the overall population of international financial regulatory institutions on the basis of the analysis of an individual bodies face the challenge of establishing where each institution issue fits within the broader population, and to what extent the area being investigated is an outlier rather than representative of a broader trend. Different approaches are required in this case.

The existing literature has developed over the years a number of approaches to analyze a broader range of inter-institutional ties beyond single case studies. One such approach relies on on capturing self-reported ties among institutions captured via surveys.2.

Other scholars have mapped formal links, partnerships agreements, memoranda of understanding, and other official collaboration ties between organizations (Perez, Cohen, and Schreiber 2019; Murdie 2013; Atouba and Shumate 2010; Sommerer and Tallberg 2019; Yi and Scholz 2016), or at shared membership across international institutions as a proxy for inter-institutional relations (Haftel and Lenz 2021).

Other works have moved past formal institutional ties among different institutions by institutions and focused on their policy output, mapped by exploring the content of the documents produced by these bodies. This approach is presented is presented by Jessica F. Green (2017) as a “more robust and internally valid measure of the relationship between rule-making organizations”. In this study we build upon this approach.

3.2 Corpus

In order to map the evolution in the international financial regulatory regime we have investigated the policy output of a number of international institutions active in this domain by exploring the publicly available documents found on their websites. Other studies have analysed similar data sources, scraping the websites of international organizations in order to extract variety of of rules, standards, treaties, codes of conduct, agreements, etc… (Jessica F. Green 2021; Jessica F. Green 2013; Pratt 2018).

This type of data is preferable to other textual sources such as news report and other digital media since these have significant limitations and bias, especially in areas such as the work of often obscure international organizations. At the same time, the range of documents and organizations covered in our dataset is much more heterogeneous that it is the case for studies analysing laws and decrees from a single country (Vannoni, Ash, and Morelli 2021b). While laws and decrees constitute separate actions which do not need to be deconflicted for redundancy (Ahn 2017a), the same is not the case for our corpus. Moreover, the terminology is more likely to vary across multiple organizations such as those involved in the international financial regime compared to the analysis of a single organization.

We select these institutions on the basis of the profile that they occupy in the international regulatory architecture, focusing in particular on those international bodies that are represented in the membership of the Financial Stability Board, plus the G7 and G20. All the institutions included in the dataset include in their mandate the role of regulating different aspects of global financial markets or have tackled this issue.

The table below summarizes the websites that we scraped, the number of documents that each website delivered, and the time coverage of the data collected.

This include all the PDFs posted in the publications page of these organizations’ website since the origin. We included in our analysis only documents that represented the view of the whole organization, excluding documents representing the view of a specific individual within the organization (e.g. speech by the head of the BCBS, research paper signed by OECD official where excluded). We also included in our analysis documents that addressed topics of international relevance, excluded country-specific reports and publications. We include in our collection only policy documents, excluding other documents such as press-releases, newsletters, briefs. We also exclude documents that are not written in English.

In the case of international organizations such as the World Bank, OECD, and IMF whose mandate goes beyond financial policies, we filtered only those documents whose topic was tagged as dealing with financial issues by the organization.

For most institutions, we were able to collect the entire population of policy documents posted on their website. An important exception here is the International Accounting Standards Board, where only documents from 2007 onwards were posted on the website.

A complete list of the documents that comprise the corpus can be found in the Appendix (Section 9.1).

3.3 Mapping References to other organizations

To identifies the interaction between the international institution, the first step is to identify all the international institutions named in the text. Textual analysis of cross-references across institutions are common in the study of different domestic legal systems (for a review, see Kim 2013), but they have also been interpreted as giving insights into the aggregate ties across institutions that comprise an international regime (Jessica F. Green 2013, 2017; Murdie 2013; Lupu and Voeten 2012; Ahlström and Cornell 2018). For instance, Ahlström and Cornell (2018) looks at how international agreements cite other agreements that they consider relevant. Kim (2013) develops a network analysis of international environmental law, mapping cross-references between different multilateral environmental agreements. Jessica F. Green (2013) maps the network of transnational carbon governance initiatives, both public and private.

The most common approach to achieve this objective in political science is through a dictionary-based approach, whereby we use an expert-generated list of terms that capture the entity of interest. As a starting point we take the list of formal and informal organizations collected by Roger (2020). This consisted of an initial list of 743 formal and informal International organizations, including their full name and acronyms.

As any dictionary-based approach, this approach tends to produce a significant number of false negatives since it is unlikely for existing dictionaries to be able to fit different projects (Shaffer 2022). We thus seek to complement complement the dictionary-based analysis by an off-the-shelf named entity recognition models designed to identify “named entities” within our corpus3. We then manually analyze the name of the entities that are most frequently recognized by the algorithm but excluded from the dictionary in order to identify false negatives. This includes a variety of organizations not included in the original dictionary, but also a number of alternative spellings and formulations of the name of organizations included in the initial dictionary (e.g. “Group of Twenty Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors”, “G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors”, “G-20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors”). These additional terms are added to the dictionary.

In addition to looking for the full name of the organization, we also search for the acronym of the same institution (e.g. BCBS instead of Basel Committee for Banking Supervision). While searching for the full name often results in numerous false negatives, trying to identify the organization by the acronym frequently generates significant amount of false positives. For instance, the acronym for the International Association of Seismology (IAS) is often used in financial governance to refer to “International Accounting Standards”. To detect these false negatives we have conducted manual spot checks on the most frequently used acronyms, and manually removed those that are not identifying reliably the intended organization. In order to limit the possibility that the inclusion of acronyms in the dictionary may result in false positives, we only consider exact matches and exclude instances when the sentence is capitalized.

3.4 Entity Resolution

Identify references to other institution presents different entity resolution problems. A common issue in recognizing entities cited in a document is in those cases where these are referred using a pronoun or a definite noun phrase (e.g. “the organization”, “the board”), so called anaphoric references (van Atteveldt, Kleinnijenhuis, and Ruigrok (2008)). In cases when the lemmas “we” and “our” are used as part of the nominal phrase that acts as subject of a verb, this is associated with the organization that has authored the document.

A more complicated entity resolution issue derives from the defining the institution by the generic name of one its sub-component, such as in the case of the term “working group”, “group”, “committee”, “Task Force”., When one of these terms are found in the title of the document, then simple references to these terms in the text are treated as making reference to the organization that is the author of the document.

Other entity resolution adjustments instead are specific to a given institution. For instance, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision refers to itself as simply “The Committee”. Likewise the International Monetary Fund refers itself as “the Fund” and IOSCO refers often to the specific committee that expressed a position (e.g. Technical Committee). We therefore attribute the term “Committee” to the BCBS in cases when the BCBS is the author on the case this is in the same sentence as terms directly pointing to the Basel Committee (e.g. “Basel”, “BCBS”).

Vannoni, Ash, and Morelli (2021b) identify as one of the potential obstacles that of co-referencing, that is, “the use of a pronoun as a subject of a sentence which refers to a subject of a previous sentence”. Since the dependency parsing adopted in our study (discussed below) takes place within each sentence, we are not able to identify these cases where the subject or object is referred to by a pronoun. For instance in the example “IOSCO has published a new report. It has disseminated the with the relevant stakeholders” we are not able to capture that IOSCO is the subject of both sentences.

3.5 Interpretation of the References to other Institutions

The interpretation of the references to other institutions is not straightforward. The existing literature acknowledges that there are different reasons why an international agreement may cross-reference another organization.

For instance, Kim (2013) argues that references to other organizations and agreements in the work of an institution could be to “acknowledge the positive relevance of the cited agreement on the issue and build upon it”, “to include the basic norms previously articulated in those instruments”, or to “to define the relationship between the citing and the cited agreements”. Jessica F. Green (2017) argues that the references made to another rule could be either “strong interactions” such as incorporating or accepting the standards of another organization and “weak interactions” such as building on or adapting contents of other standards. Different scholars have tried to systematize these different types of interaction captured by textual citations by providing taxonomy. For instance Perez and Stegmann (2018) identify different types of citation types: “incorporation” (compliance with another standards/rule), “partial grounding” (drawing in some ways on the initiative by the other institution), “textual indication of collaboration”, and “acknowledgments”. Pratt (2018) differentiates between five different types of references: “Passing Reference” to the work of other organizations on a matter no relevant, “Rule Reference” to the activities of another organization in the issue area, “intent to coordinate” with another organization, “Cooperative Action and Rule Endorsement” between two institutions, or the explicit acceptance of the authority of another organization (“deference”).

Differentiating between the different types of interactions often requires the researcher to manually code the individual cross-references found in the text, thus limiting the capacity to increase the scale of the analysis. In this study we turn instead to natural language processing to achieve this goal.

3.6 Natural Language Processing

In order to enhance the capacity our capacity to extract information from the policy documents produced by different organizations regarding their interaction with other bodies in this paper we turn to “natural language processing” (NLP), in particular dependency parsing.

NLP approaches differ significantly from so-called “bag of words” approach that inform most of the previous attempts to rely on quantitative text analysis to investigate regime complexes. For instance, different studies have used topic modelling to observe to what extent organizations are working on similar topics based on the co-occurrence of terms in the documents produced by these bodies (Pratt 2018; Jessica F. Green 2021).

Bag of words approaches break down the text in as a sequence of tokens or phrases and focus on analyzing word frequency, co-occurrence, or semantic distances derived from co-occurrence. As a result, they ignore a large amount of information regarding the semantic relations found in the text that is emerging from the language structure. This includes informations regarding the relation between the different entities identified in the text. As Stuhler (2022) argues, “rather than whether A and B co-occur or are similar… [we] often want to know what A does to B and vice versa.” Along the same lines, Ahn (2016) argues that “if researchers need to know whether”the President dismissed Parliament” or “Parliament dismissed the President,” a bag-of-words approach would treat these two statements the same. Word order matters, as do common connector words like prepositions that a bag of words approach might throw out as uninformative without their immediate context.”

On the contrary NLP (synctactic parsing) approaches go beyond simply looking at the analysis of word counts alone to also take into account the grammatical patterns and explore both semantic and syntactic information beyond what is included in a list of tokens (Vannoni, Ash, and Morelli 2021b).

The approach adopted in this paper instead seeks to extract more accurate information on the semantic relations found in the text between different entities that co-occur in the same documents (O’Connor, Stewart, and Smith 2013). This emphasis on a “relational approach towards studying texts” (Stuhler 2022) has a long history. For instance, Franzosi calls for studying events by identifying in the relational statements that document contents in the form of of “semantic triplets” composed of the form subject-action-object (Franzosi 1989). Over the years an extensive literature has focused on automating the extraction in a structured format of the information regarding actions, the involved actors, place, and time of the actions related to “political events” (King and Lowe 2003; Beieler et al. 2016; Halterman 2020).

The dominant approach to extract information from text regarding political events often relied on the use of manually constructed dictionaries and phrase patterns. In particular since the 1980s, political scientists have developed different automated rule-based extraction systems relying on extensive hand-developed phrase dictionaries (Schrodt and Gerner 1994), often containing list of actors and actions created for specific projects (see for instance King and Lowe 2003; Brathwaite and Park 2019; Norris, Schrodt, and Beieler 2017). Dictionary-based methods have important limitations, such as the significant resources required to construct them and the fact they cannot be used to discover new event types, new actors, or actions beyond those that have already been included in the dictionary (Halterman 2020).

Advances in NLPs have made it easier to integrate grammatical information to determine not just which actors and actions were involved but also to identify more accurately the direction of the action and “who did what to whom” (Ahn 2017a). It is worth nothing that additional works in recent years have pushed the role of automated text analysis even further by developing approaches to identify event types and roles within the text inductively from the text (Ahn 2017a, 2017b), although this is not the approach adopted here.

In the net section we outline the approach adopted in this paper to achieve this objective.

3.7 Dependency Parsing

The first step is that of sentence segmentation, that is the process of identifying the boundaries of individual sentences. Each sentence is then tokenized and each token is assigned a tag according to its function. This steps involves, for instance, differentiating between verbs, nouns, pronouns, adjectives, etc… In this paper this function is performed a “part-of-speech tagger” trained on a manually annotated corpus of these tags, predicting the likelihood that a token should be assigned a given tag given the content and the context of the word (Vannoni, Ash, and Morelli 2021a).

The next step is then to extract information on the relationship between different words in the sentence. This information is provided by the so-called synctactic “dependency parsing”. A dependency parser relies on a given dependency grammar to define the range of possible dependency relations across lexical units in the sentence. Dependency parsers are trained on a corpus of manually annotated syntactic dependencies, called dependency treebanks, to determine how each word is related to other words in the same sentence.

While there are different processing pipelines which include dependency parsing, in this paper we use the spaCy library (Honnibal et al. 2020), as implemented in R by the spacyr package (Benoit and Matsuo 2020). This is an open-source tool that generate sentence segmentation, tokenization, POS tagging, lemmatization and dependency parsing”. The annotation scheme is based on (universal) Stanford dependency scheme (DeMarneffeStanfordTypedDependencies2008?), which provides a set of universal grammatical relations (Marneffe et al. 2014).

This process involves identifying information on the syntactic relations between different words in the same sentence that derive from the grammatical structure of the sentence. This process, for instance, involves identifying whether a verb is the main verb or an auxiliary, whether a noun is the subject or the object, etc… (Vannoni, Ash, and Morelli 2021a).

The results are expressed as a series of dependency relations, whereby each words in a sentence is related to at least another through a functional dependency. As a result, a sentence can be represented as a “parse tree” where a single token represent the root of the sentence, each token is dependent on another one, and there is a unique path from each word to a common root (de Marneffe and Nivre 2019).

library(ggraph)

size = 3
Selected_Doc <- "44739159"
Selected_Sentence_ID <- 17
Selected_Sentence <- rio::import(paste0("POS/POS_", Selected_Doc, ".csv")) %>%
  filter(sentence_id == Selected_Sentence_ID)

 Selected_Sentence <- Selected_Sentence %>%
   filter(pos != "PUNCT") %>%
   filter(token_id <7)
   
  edges <- Selected_Sentence[Selected_Sentence$head_token_id != 0, c("token_id", "head_token_id", "dep_rel")]
  edges$label <- edges$dep_rel
  vertices = Selected_Sentence %>%
    select(token_id, token, pos)
  
  g <- graph_from_data_frame(edges,
                             vertices,
                             directed = TRUE)
  ggraph(g, layout = "linear") +
    theme_graph(base_family = "Arial Narrow") +
    geom_edge_arc(ggplot2::aes(label = dep_rel, vjust = -0.35),
               arrow = grid::arrow(length = unit(2, 'mm'), ends = "last", type = "closed"),
               end_cap = ggraph::label_rect("wordswordswords"),
               label_colour = "red", check_overlap = TRUE, label_size = size*1) +
     geom_node_text(ggplot2::aes(label = pos), nudge_y = -0.15, size = size)+
    geom_node_label(ggplot2::aes(label = token), nudge_y = 0, col = "darkgreen", fill = "white", size = size*1, fontface = "bold")

A few works have in recent years applied the use of dependency parsing to the study of political science and political economy (O’Connor, Stewart, and Smith 2013; van Atteveldt, Kleinnijenhuis, and Ruigrok 2008; Vannoni, Ash, and Morelli 2021b; Vannoni 2021) but to the best of our knowledge this approach has not been used to analyze the relation between international institutions.

3.8 Ties Extraction

Using the results of the POS tag and dependency parsing we identify “event tuples” (O’Connor, Stewart, and Smith 2013) that comprise the “source” and “receiver” arguments, which are political actor entities in a predefined list, a timestamp derived from the document’s published date, and “verb-based dependency path”(O’Connor, Stewart, and Smith 2013).

Similar to O’Connor, Stewart, and Smith (2013), the approach adopted in this paper focuses on identifying actions initiated by one international institution targeted towards another. The assumption is that all interactions are anchored on a verb.

From each sentence we extract the main action verbs and entities associated with these verbs in certain grammatical positions. After having identified the syntactic role that different entities have in the sentence, we need to identify their semantic roles. We focus in particular on identifying the “source” of the action, that is the actor doing or causing something, and the “target” of the action, that is the actor or entitity that this is done to (van Atteveldt, Kleinnijenhuis, and Ruigrok 2008). This requires to analyse the predicate to determine whether the sentence is active or passive. If the sentence is active, the subject node of the main verb is identified as the semantic “source” of the action. We instead identify as the semantic “target” those actors that are part of phrasal expressions that are flagged as direct objects (such as IOSCO in “The G20 endorse IOSCO’s work)” or propositional object to the same verb (such as the World Bank in the example “The IMF coordinate with the World Bank” or “The IMF work alongside the World Bank”) . For passive sentences instead, the syntactic subject (nsubjpass) is the semantic object, while the propositional object (tagged “agent”) is the semantic subject. Moreover, we also consider paths that includes multiword construction where the name of the entity is part of a nominal phrase that is either the subject or the object of the verb, such as “IOSCO’s principles” or “BCBS standards”.

Once we have identified instances when institutions are listed as sources and targets in the same sentence, we then identify the shortest path through that verb linking the two organizations.

Some dependency path may involve more than a single verb. For instance an institution may “continue to support” or “endorse the statement introduced by” another organization. In addition to simple clauses where the dependents of the predicate are nominal phrases, we also consider verb chains where a subordinate clause acts as dependent of the predicate at the root of the sentence (de Marneffe et al. 2021, 272).

We are interested in capturing instances of actual interactions/ties between institutions that are reported or self-reported in these documents rather than hypotheticals. To do this we limit the analysis to instances to path involving the verb at the root of the sentence or a verb connected by a coordinating conjunction with the verb at the root of the sentence (for a similar approach, see O’Connor, Stewart, and Smith 2013).

In the case the verb is connected by a coordinating conjunction to another verb and these have a common subject, we travel through the dependency path and identify the common subject (e.g. IOSCO is the subject of “decided” in the sentence “IOSCO has investigated the issue and decided to support the BCBS’s standards”)

In line with O’Connor, Stewart, and Smith (2013), we remove instances where the path connecting two organizations contains a parataxis relation linking is a pair of what could have been standalone sentences, verbal paths where two verbs are connected by a coordinating conjunctions (conj), or instances when the parser is unable to determine a relation between different terms (dep). We filter ties where the path between the two institutions is longer that 4 steps (==PROVIDE EXAMPLE==). We also remove instances when the same organization is both the source and the target of the verbal path (e.g. a G20 statement that reads “We reiterate the importance of the G20 Action Plan”).

Identifying phrasal verbs represent one of the thorniest problems for natural language processing given their possible continuous and discontinuous nature, the possible confusion with verbs followed by simple preposition, and possible ambiguities that require careful analysis of the context (Machonis 2018). In this paper follow a simply approach to identify phrasal verbs by matching the verbs extracted by the analysis and the consecutive preposition against against a list of 3222 phrasal verbs by Wikipedia

3.9 Extraction Rules

After having identified the dependency-based path that link different entities in the same sentence, the next step is to aggregated these across different theoretically motivated categories, regardless of the specific terminology or verb used (Halterman 2020).In order to do so, we need to specify additional extraction rules to determine which syntactic structures identified by the dependency parser need to be mapped to specific semantic structures.

Since the definition of the extraction rules are tried to dependency relations between words in a sentence, they are not constrained by word order. As Vannoni, Ash, and Morelli (2021b) puts it, this allows for “a classification of sentences according to their meaning, with information on the agents involved”.

4 Analysis of References to Other Institutions

A first type of analysis of this data involves looking at the relationship between the author of the document and the organization being cited.

4.1 Frequency of documents citing other institutions

The figure below shows the percentage of documents published by each organization in our dataset that cite a different institution. The figure shows that it is common for the documents issued by these international organizations to cite at least another institution. In 14 out of 16 institutions, 75% of the documents make reference to at least another institution. The two exceptions are the World Bank and International Accounting Sta ndards Board.

4.2 Number of Institutions cited

The figure below shows the average number of institutions cited by different institutions in each document. This shows greater variance across different bodies.

The figure below looks at the evolution in the number of institutions cited across time. Overall, a uniform trend is not visible. An upward trend is clearly visible for many institutions (e.g. IOSCO, BCBS, OECD). In the case of the FSB this instead has decreased, possibly signalling a greater role for the organization in recent years in setting policies rather than reporting on the work of other bodies.

4.3 Who is Citing Whom?

The table below illustrate the most commonly cited organizations by each of the institutions in our corpus.

Not all of the citations are meaningful. For instance, the fact that 76% of the BCBS documents mention the BIS could reflect boilerplate language given the fact that the institution is housed within the BCBS.

5 Analysis of the Verbs associated with References to Other Institutions

A second type of analysis of this seeks to extract more information on the meaning of the citation by looking at the at the relationship between the organization being cited (the agent) and the action (verb) associated with this institution. In other words, we can observe when an institution discusses the actions taken by other institutions.

IO_Verb %>%
  filter(IO_Agent != IO_Author) %>%
  #select(-ID.x) %>%
  distinct() %>%
    arrange(Verb_Combined, nchar(Sentence)) %>%
    group_by(Verb_Combined) %>% 
    mutate(Num_Sentences = n_distinct(Sentence)) %>%
  select(Verb_Combined, Num_Sentences, Sentence) %>%
  distinct() %>%
    mutate(rank = rank(nchar(Sentence), ties.method = "first")) %>%
    filter(rank < 3) %>%
  filter(Num_Sentences>100) %>%
  mutate(Label = paste0(Verb_Combined, " (", Num_Sentences, ")")) %>%
    group_by(Label) %>% 
    summarise(Examples = paste0(Sentence, collapse = "<br><br>")) %>%
    gt()  %>%
      fmt_markdown(columns = everything())

6 Analysis of Ties Across Institutions

The findings presented in the previous section concerned the relationship between the actions (verb) associated with institutions (as subject of these verbs) cited by other bodies. This captures what roles and actions by different institutions are mentioned/discussed by different bodies.

These actions however are not necessarily targeted at a different body (e.g. “The BCBS is an organization”). In this section we focus on a subset of the previous analysis where different international institutions are both the agent and the target of the same verb.

6.1 Presence of Ties In the Corpus

While references to a different institution are ubiquitous in the corpus, reported verb-based paths linking two different institutions are found in a minority of the documents in the corpus.

Code 
Temp <- IO_Ties %>%
    group_by(Title_Text) %>%
    summarize(Num_Ties = n()) 

AllReg_Edit <- AllReg %>%
    left_join(Temp) %>%
    mutate(Num_Ties = replace_na(Num_Ties, 0)) %>%
    mutate(Num_Ties_Binary = ifelse(
        Num_Ties == 0,
        "No Ties",
        "Ties"
    ))

#Create count of documents with ties
Perc_Doc_Ties <- round(100*sum(AllReg_Edit$Num_Ties_Binary == "Ties") / nrow(AllReg_Edit),1)  

#Plot distribution of ties across documents
ggplot(data = AllReg_Edit) +
    geom_bar(
        mapping = aes(x = Num_Ties_Binary)
        ) +
    labs (title = "Documents with reported ties",
          x = "",
          y = "Number of Ties") +
    theme_minimal()

6.5 Path including multiple verbs

The analysis currently also includes paths linking two bodies that include multiple verbs. The table below illustatrates the most frequent combinations with some examples.

In some cases the second verb is the meaningful one (e.g. “continue to support”). In other cases the first verb is the one capturing the relationship between the two organizations (IAIS and IOSCO evaluate International Accounting Standards developed by the International Accounting Standards Board” )

A few options: - we can limit the analyusis to direct paths where two organizations are connected by one verb - we can identify those cases where the first verb strengthens the second verb and retain the second verb (e.g. continues to support) - we can identify those cases where the first verb is the meaningful one and and retain the first verb

Code 
IO_Ties %>%
   mutate(Second_Verb = na_if(Second_Verb,"")) %>%
  drop_na(Second_Verb) %>%
    arrange(Verb_Combined, nchar(Sentence)) %>%
    group_by(Verb_Combined) %>% 
    mutate(Num_Sentences = n_distinct(Title_Text_Sentence)) %>%
  select(Verb_Combined, Num_Sentences, Sentence) %>%
  distinct() %>%
    mutate(rank = rank(nchar(Sentence), ties.method = "first")) %>%
    filter(rank < 3) %>%
  filter(Num_Sentences>3) %>%
  arrange(-Num_Sentences) %>%
  mutate(Label = paste0(Verb_Combined, " (", Num_Sentences, ")")) %>%
    group_by(Label) %>% 
    summarise(Examples = paste0(Sentence, collapse = "<br><br>")) %>%
    gt()  %>%
      fmt_markdown(columns = everything())
Label Examples

The Insurance Core Principles and Methodology were revised to take into account comments of members ( particularly arising as a result of their experience with the self - assessment exercise ) , the IMF and World Bank experience in conducting assessments , the Joint Forum work on comparing the Core Principles of the IAIS , IOSCO and the BCBS , and comments from relevant IAIS subcommittees .

A Task Force is working to revise the Insurance Core Principles and accompanying methodology taking into account comments of members ( particularly arising as a result of their experience with the self- assessment exercise ) , the IMF and World Bank experience in conducting assessments , the Joint Forum work on comparing the Core Principles of the IAIS , IOSCO and the BCBS , and comments from relevant IAIS subcommittees .

Brief Description : A Task Force is working to revise the Insurance Core Principles and accompanying methodology taking into account comments of members ( particularly arising as a result of their experience with the self - assessment exercise ) , the IMF and World Bank experience in conducting assessments , the Joint Forum work on comparing the Core Principles of the IAIS , IOSCO and the BCBS , and comments from relevant IAIS subcommittees .

6.7 Welcome

  • Most common verb linking two organizations in the dataset
  • Most commonly it links a subject to a djob (e.g. “We welcome the latest joint report from the WTO , OECD , IMF”), but in some cases also a pobj (“We welcome the work by the BCBS and IOSCO”). The difference between pobj adn dobj largely depends on whether the parser regards the preposition closer to the verb as dependent on the verb or on the dobj

6.7.1 Examples

Code 
IO_Ties %>%
    filter(Near_Verb == "welcome") %>%
    arrange(Verb_Combined, nchar(Sentence)) %>%
    group_by(Verb_Combined) %>% 
    mutate(Num_Sentences = n_distinct(Title_Text_Sentence)) %>%
  select(Verb_Combined, Num_Sentences, Sentence) %>%
  distinct() %>%
    mutate(rank = rank(nchar(Sentence), ties.method = "first")) %>%
    filter(rank < 6) %>%
  filter(Num_Sentences>4) %>%
  arrange(-Num_Sentences) %>%
  mutate(Verb = paste0(Verb_Combined, " (", Num_Sentences, ")")) %>%
    group_by(Verb) %>% 
    summarise(Examples = paste0(Sentence, collapse = "<br><br>")) %>%
    gt() %>%
    fmt_markdown(columns = everything())
Verb Examples

welcome --> make (15)

We welcome the progress made by FATF in identifying and monitoring high - risk jurisdictions with

The IAASB therefore welcomes the further progress made by the IASB in its disclosure initiative .

 We welcome the efforts made by the OECD and the AfDB ’s AFMI to build up securities statistics in African countries .

We welcomed the announcement made by the UN regarding a preparatory meeting for an international conference on the reconstruction of Iraq .

In this connection , the Group welcomed the progress made by the World Bank , in co - operation with other relevant bodies , in its work on Insolvency Principles .

welcome --> take (6)

We welcome the steps taken by the IMF to become a more open and transparent institution .

We welcome the determined actions taken by the European Union , the European Central Bank and the IMF .

We also welcome the steps taken by the Security Council to ensure clear and fair procedures within sanctions regimes .

We welcome the decision recently taken by the World Bank Group to better utilise its balance sheet to increase its lending capacity .

We welcome the actions being taken by the World Bank and other Multilateral Development Banks ( MDBs ) that highlight their important countercyclical role in responding to the global crisis .

welcome (452)

We welcomed the FSB 's outreach .

We welcome improvements to the UN al-

We welcome the IMF 's progress in these areas .

We welcome the IMF Managing DirectorÕs Strategic Review .

We welcome the ongoing work of the OECD on this subject .

6.7.2 Who is “welcoming” whom?

Welcome as a verb is used almost exclusively by the G20/G7, so it is very specific to “political” bodies.

Code 
IO_Ties %>%
    filter (Near_Verb == "welcome") %>%
  group_by(IO_Agent) %>%
  count() %>%
  arrange(-n) %>%
  ungroup %>%
  gt()
IO_Agent n
G7 310
G20 292
FATF 14
OECD 13
FSB 10
IMF 2
EAG 1
IAASB 1
UN 1
WB 1

The network visualization below illustrates who is “welcoming” whom.

Code 
Welcome_Ties <- IO_Ties %>%
    filter (Near_Verb == "welcome")

#Create nodelist
Nodes_DF <- tibble(IO = unique(c(Welcome_Ties$IO_Agent, Welcome_Ties$IO_Target)))
Nodes_DF$ID = 1:nrow(Nodes_DF)
Nodes_DF <- Nodes_DF %>% select(ID, IO)
    
#Create edgelist
Edge_DF <- Welcome_Ties %>%
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  summarize(Num_Ties = n()) %>%
  left_join(Nodes_DF, by = c("IO_Agent"="IO")) %>%
  left_join(Nodes_DF, by = c("IO_Target"="IO")) %>%
  select(ID.x, ID.y, everything()) 
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'IO_Agent'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.
Code 
library(tidygraph)
Net <- tbl_graph(nodes = Nodes_DF, edges = Edge_DF, directed = TRUE)

library(visNetwork) 
Net %>% 
  activate(nodes) %>%
  mutate(label = IO) %>%
  activate(edges) %>%
  mutate(width = Num_Ties) %>%
  as.igraph() %>%
  visIgraph(idToLabel = FALSE,
            layout = "layout_nicely") %>%
    visNodes(scaling = list(min = 10, max = 30),
           color = list(background = "lightblue", 
                        border = "darkblue",
                        highlight = NA),
           shadow = list(enabled = TRUE, size = 10)) %>%
  visEdges(shadow = FALSE)%>%
    visOptions(highlightNearest = TRUE,
               nodesIdSelection = TRUE) %>%
    visInteraction(navigationButtons = TRUE)

An analysis of this verb would need to focus on the target rather than the source

7 Analysis of international organizations

Below we zoom in on specific organizations and summarise their ties with other bodies

7.1 BCBS

Code 
IO <- "BCBS"

7.1.1 BCBS as Agent

Code 
  IO_Out <- IO_Ties %>%
    #Filter ties with the selected IO
    filter(IO_Agent == IO) %>%
    ## Identify the number of ties among pairs of agent/target 
    group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
    mutate(Number_Reference_Total = n()) %>%
    ungroup() %>%
    # Identify the  most common pairs across agent/target and filter
    mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = dense_rank(desc(Number_Reference_Total))) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total<8) %>%
     #identify the most common path for the same agent/target
 group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target, Number_Reference_Total, Verb_Combined) %>%
  summarize(Number_Reference = n()) %>%
   mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = rank(desc(Number_Reference), ties.method='first')) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total==1)
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'IO_Agent', 'IO_Target',
'Number_Reference_Total'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.
Code 
#Create nodelist

Nodes_DF$ID = 1:nrow(Nodes_DF)

#Add Number Reference total
Temp <- IO_Out %>%
  select(IO_Target, Number_Reference_Total)

  left_join(Temp,  by = c("IO"="IO_Target"))
  Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total <- rescale(Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total, to = c(5, 10))

Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total[Nodes_DF$IO==IO] <- 15

Nodes_DF$color <- "Red"

  left_join(Nodes_DF, by = c("IO_Agent"="IO")) %>%

  #Filter ties with the selected IO
  filter(IO_Target == IO) %>%
  ## Identify the number of ties among pairs of agent/target 
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  mutate(Number_Reference_Total = n()) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # Identify the  most common pairs across agent/target and filter
  mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = dense_rank(desc(Number_Reference_Total))) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total<8) %>%
     #identify the most common path for the same agent/target
 group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target, Number_Reference_Total, Verb_Combined) %>%

   mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = rank(desc(Number_Reference), ties.method='first')) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total==1)

#Add Number Reference total
Temp <- IO_In %>% ungroup() %>%
  select(IO_Agent, Number_Reference_Total)
Nodes_DF <- Nodes_DF %>%
  left_join(Temp,  by = c("IO"="IO_Agent"))
  Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total <- rescale(Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total, to = c(5, 10))
#Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total[Nodes_DF$IO==IO] <- sum(Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total, na.rm = T)

# Add the node colour
Nodes_DF$color <- "Orange"
Nodes_DF$color[Nodes_DF$IO==IO] <- "Red"


#Create edgelist
Edge_DF <- IO_In %>%
  left_join(Nodes_DF, by = c("IO_Agent"="IO")) %>%
  left_join(Nodes_DF, by = c("IO_Target"="IO")) %>%
  select(ID.x, ID.y, everything())

library(visNetwork) 
library(scales)

  activate(nodes) %>%
  mutate(label = IO) %>%
  mutate(value = rescale(Number_Reference_Total))%>%

  #mutate(value = rescale(Number_Reference, to = c(0.5, 0.8)))%>%

            layout = "layout_nicely") %>%

IO_Ties %>%
  #Filter ties with the selected IO
  filter(IO_Agent == IO) %>%
  ## Identify the number of ties among pairs of agent/target 
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  mutate(Number_Reference_Total = n()) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # Identify the  most common pairs across agent/target and filter
  mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = dense_rank(desc(Number_Reference_Total))) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total<10) %>%
     #identify the most common path for the same agent/target
 group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target, Path_Short) %>%
  mutate(Number_Reference = n()) %>%
    #identify the shortest sentence for the same combination of agent/target/path_short
  mutate(sentenceLength = nchar(Sentence)) %>%
  mutate(rankSentenceLength = rank(sentenceLength, ties.method='first')) %>% 
  filter(rankSentenceLength== 1) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  
   #filter the most common path for the same agent/target
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  mutate(rankNumberReference = rank(desc(Number_Reference), ties.method='first')) %>%
  filter(rankNumberReference<=3) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # Arrange

                                  " --> ", 
                                  IO_Target, 
                                  " (", 
                                  Number_Reference_Total, 
                                  ")"

  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = paste0("Most Common Ties with ", IO, " as source")
  )  %>%

    Path_Short = "Path",
    Number_Reference = "N. References",

Code 
  IO_Out <- IO_Ties %>%
    #Filter ties with the selected IO
    filter(IO_Agent == IO) %>%
    ## Identify the number of ties among pairs of agent/target 
    group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
    mutate(Number_Reference_Total = n()) %>%
    ungroup() %>%
    # Identify the  most common pairs across agent/target and filter
    mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = dense_rank(desc(Number_Reference_Total))) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total<8) %>%
     #identify the most common path for the same agent/target
 group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target, Number_Reference_Total, Verb_Combined) %>%
  summarize(Number_Reference = n()) %>%
   mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = rank(desc(Number_Reference), ties.method='first')) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total==1)

Net <- tbl_graph(nodes = Nodes_DF, edges = Edge_DF, directed = TRUE)

library(visNetwork) 
library(scales)

Net %>% 
  activate(nodes) %>%
  mutate(label = IO) %>%
  mutate(value = rescale(Number_Reference_Total))%>%
  activate(edges) %>%
  #mutate(value = rescale(Number_Reference, to = c(0.5, 0.8)))%>%
  mutate(label = Verb_Combined) %>%
  mutate(font.color = "red") %>%
  mutate(font.size = 15) %>%
  as.igraph() %>%
  visIgraph(idToLabel = FALSE,
            layout = "layout_nicely") %>%
    visNodes(scaling = list(min = 10, max = 30),
           color = list(background = "lightblue", 
                        border = "darkblue",
                        highlight = NA),
           shadow = list(enabled = TRUE, size = 10)) %>%
  visEdges(shadow = FALSE,
           arrows = "to")%>%
    visOptions(highlightNearest = TRUE,
               nodesIdSelection = TRUE) %>%
    visInteraction(navigationButtons = TRUE)

7.3.3 Examples of FSB Ties

The table below provides examples of the most common path where this organization is the agent taking actions directed at other organizations.

Code 
IO_Ties %>%
  #Filter ties with the selected IO
  filter(IO_Agent == IO) %>%
  ## Identify the number of ties among pairs of agent/target 
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  mutate(Number_Reference_Total = n()) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # Identify the  most common pairs across agent/target and filter
  mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = dense_rank(desc(Number_Reference_Total))) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total<10) %>%
     #identify the most common path for the same agent/target
 group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target, Path_Short) %>%
  mutate(Number_Reference = n()) %>%
    #identify the shortest sentence for the same combination of agent/target/path_short
  mutate(sentenceLength = nchar(Sentence)) %>%
  mutate(rankSentenceLength = rank(sentenceLength, ties.method='first')) %>% 
  filter(rankSentenceLength== 1) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  
   #filter the most common path for the same agent/target
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  mutate(rankNumberReference = rank(desc(Number_Reference), ties.method='first')) %>%
  filter(rankNumberReference<=3) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # Arrange
  arrange(desc(Number_Reference_Total), desc(Number_Reference)) %>%
  # Create Composite Label with path and frequency
  mutate(label_composite = paste0(IO_Agent, 
                                  " --> ", 
                                  IO_Target, 
                                  " (", 
                                  Number_Reference_Total, 
                                  ")"
                                  )) %>%
  group_by(label_composite) %>%
  select(Path_Short, Number_Reference, Sentence) %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = paste0("Most Common Ties with ", IO, " as source")
  )  %>%
  cols_label(
    Path_Short = "Path",
    Number_Reference = "N. References",
    Sentence = "Example"
  ) %>%
  cols_align(
    align = "center",
    columns = everything()
    )

IO <- "WB"

7.5.1 WB as Agent

Code 
  IO_Out <- IO_Ties %>%
    #Filter ties with the selected IO
    filter(IO_Agent == IO) %>%
    ## Identify the number of ties among pairs of agent/target 
    group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
    mutate(Number_Reference_Total = n()) %>%
    ungroup() %>%
    # Identify the  most common pairs across agent/target and filter
    mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = dense_rank(desc(Number_Reference_Total))) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total<8) %>%
     #identify the most common path for the same agent/target
 group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target, Number_Reference_Total, Verb_Combined) %>%
  summarize(Number_Reference = n()) %>%
   mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = rank(desc(Number_Reference), ties.method='first')) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total==1)
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'IO_Agent', 'IO_Target',
'Number_Reference_Total'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.
Code 
#Create nodelist
Nodes_DF <- tibble(IO = unique(c(IO_Out$IO_Agent, IO_Out$IO_Target)))
Nodes_DF$ID = 1:nrow(Nodes_DF)
Nodes_DF <- Nodes_DF %>% select(ID, IO)

#Add Number Reference total
Temp <- IO_Out %>%
  select(IO_Target, Number_Reference_Total)
Adding missing grouping variables: `IO_Agent`
Code 
Nodes_DF <- Nodes_DF %>%
  left_join(Temp,  by = c("IO"="IO_Target"))
  Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total <- rescale(Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total, to = c(5, 10))
#Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total[Nodes_DF$IO==IO] <- sum(Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total, na.rm = T)
Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total[Nodes_DF$IO==IO] <- 15

# Add the node colour
Nodes_DF$color <- "Red"
Nodes_DF$color[Nodes_DF$IO==IO] <- "Orange"


#Create edgelist
Edge_DF <- IO_Out %>%
  left_join(Nodes_DF, by = c("IO_Agent"="IO")) %>%
  left_join(Nodes_DF, by = c("IO_Target"="IO")) %>%
  select(ID.x, ID.y, everything()) 
  


library(tidygraph)
Net <- tbl_graph(nodes = Nodes_DF, edges = Edge_DF, directed = TRUE)

library(visNetwork) 
library(scales)

Net %>% 
  activate(nodes) %>%
  mutate(label = IO) %>%
  mutate(value = rescale(Number_Reference_Total))%>%
  activate(edges) %>%
  #mutate(value = rescale(Number_Reference, to = c(0.5, 0.8)))%>%
  mutate(label = Verb_Combined) %>%
  mutate(font.color = "red") %>%
  mutate(font.size = 15) %>%
  as.igraph() %>%
  visIgraph(idToLabel = FALSE,
            layout = "layout_nicely") %>%
    visNodes(scaling = list(min = 10, max = 30),
           color = list(background = "lightblue", 
                        border = "darkblue",
                        highlight = NA),
           shadow = list(enabled = TRUE, size = 10)) %>%
  visEdges(shadow = FALSE,
           arrows = "to")%>%
    visOptions(highlightNearest = TRUE,
               nodesIdSelection = TRUE) %>%
    visInteraction(navigationButtons = TRUE)

7.5.3 Examples of WB Ties

The table below provides examples of the most common path where this organization is the agent taking actions directed at other organizations.

Code 
IO_Ties %>%
  #Filter ties with the selected IO
  filter(IO_Agent == IO) %>%
  ## Identify the number of ties among pairs of agent/target 
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  mutate(Number_Reference_Total = n()) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # Identify the  most common pairs across agent/target and filter
  mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = dense_rank(desc(Number_Reference_Total))) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total<10) %>%
     #identify the most common path for the same agent/target
 group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target, Path_Short) %>%
  mutate(Number_Reference = n()) %>%
    #identify the shortest sentence for the same combination of agent/target/path_short
  mutate(sentenceLength = nchar(Sentence)) %>%
  mutate(rankSentenceLength = rank(sentenceLength, ties.method='first')) %>% 
  filter(rankSentenceLength== 1) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  
   #filter the most common path for the same agent/target
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  mutate(rankNumberReference = rank(desc(Number_Reference), ties.method='first')) %>%
  filter(rankNumberReference<=3) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # Arrange
  arrange(desc(Number_Reference_Total), desc(Number_Reference)) %>%
  # Create Composite Label with path and frequency
  mutate(label_composite = paste0(IO_Agent, 
                                  " --> ", 
                                  IO_Target, 
                                  " (", 
                                  Number_Reference_Total, 
                                  ")"
                                  )) %>%
  group_by(label_composite) %>%
  select(Path_Short, Number_Reference, Sentence) %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = paste0("Most Common Ties with ", IO, " as source")
  )  %>%
  cols_label(
    Path_Short = "Path",
    Number_Reference = "N. References",
    Sentence = "Example"
  ) %>%
  cols_align(
    align = "center",
    columns = everything()
    )

7.6 OECD

Code 
IO <- "OECD"

7.6.1 OECD as Agent

Code 
  IO_Out <- IO_Ties %>%
    #Filter ties with the selected IO
    filter(IO_Agent == IO) %>%
    ## Identify the number of ties among pairs of agent/target 
    group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
    mutate(Number_Reference_Total = n()) %>%
    ungroup() %>%
    # Identify the  most common pairs across agent/target and filter
    mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = dense_rank(desc(Number_Reference_Total))) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total<8) %>%
     #identify the most common path for the same agent/target
 group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target, Number_Reference_Total, Verb_Combined) %>%
  summarize(Number_Reference = n()) %>%
   mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = rank(desc(Number_Reference), ties.method='first')) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total==1)
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'IO_Agent', 'IO_Target',
'Number_Reference_Total'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.
Code 
#Create nodelist
Nodes_DF <- tibble(IO = unique(c(IO_Out$IO_Agent, IO_Out$IO_Target)))
Nodes_DF$ID = 1:nrow(Nodes_DF)
Nodes_DF <- Nodes_DF %>% select(ID, IO)

#Add Number Reference total
Temp <- IO_Out %>%
  select(IO_Target, Number_Reference_Total)
Adding missing grouping variables: `IO_Agent`
Code 
Nodes_DF <- Nodes_DF %>%
  left_join(Temp,  by = c("IO"="IO_Target"))
  Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total <- rescale(Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total, to = c(5, 10))
#Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total[Nodes_DF$IO==IO] <- sum(Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total, na.rm = T)
Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total[Nodes_DF$IO==IO] <- 15

# Add the node colour
Nodes_DF$color <- "Red"
Nodes_DF$color[Nodes_DF$IO==IO] <- "Orange"


#Create edgelist
Edge_DF <- IO_Out %>%
  left_join(Nodes_DF, by = c("IO_Agent"="IO")) %>%
  left_join(Nodes_DF, by = c("IO_Target"="IO")) %>%
  select(ID.x, ID.y, everything()) 
  


library(tidygraph)
Net <- tbl_graph(nodes = Nodes_DF, edges = Edge_DF, directed = TRUE)

library(visNetwork) 
library(scales)

Net %>% 
  activate(nodes) %>%
  mutate(label = IO) %>%
  mutate(value = rescale(Number_Reference_Total))%>%
  activate(edges) %>%
  #mutate(value = rescale(Number_Reference, to = c(0.5, 0.8)))%>%
  mutate(label = Verb_Combined) %>%
  mutate(font.color = "red") %>%
  mutate(font.size = 15) %>%
  as.igraph() %>%
  visIgraph(idToLabel = FALSE,
            layout = "layout_nicely") %>%
    visNodes(scaling = list(min = 10, max = 30),
           color = list(background = "lightblue", 
                        border = "darkblue",
                        highlight = NA),
           shadow = list(enabled = TRUE, size = 10)) %>%
  visEdges(shadow = FALSE,
           arrows = "to")%>%
    visOptions(highlightNearest = TRUE,
               nodesIdSelection = TRUE) %>%
    visInteraction(navigationButtons = TRUE)

#Create nodelist
Nodes_DF <- tibble(IO = unique(c(IO_In$IO_Agent, IO_In$IO_Target)))

  select(IO_Agent, Number_Reference_Total)

  left_join(Temp,  by = c("IO"="IO_Agent"))
  Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total <- rescale(Nodes_DF$Number_Reference_Total, to = c(5, 10))

7.6.3 Examples of OECD Ties

The table below provides examples of the most common path where this organization is the agent taking actions directed at other organizations.

Code 
IO_Ties %>%
  #Filter ties with the selected IO
  filter(IO_Agent == IO) %>%
  ## Identify the number of ties among pairs of agent/target 
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  mutate(Number_Reference_Total = n()) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # Identify the  most common pairs across agent/target and filter
  mutate(rank_Number_Reference_Total = dense_rank(desc(Number_Reference_Total))) %>%
  filter(rank_Number_Reference_Total<10) %>%
     #identify the most common path for the same agent/target
 group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target, Path_Short) %>%
  mutate(Number_Reference = n()) %>%
    #identify the shortest sentence for the same combination of agent/target/path_short
  mutate(sentenceLength = nchar(Sentence)) %>%
  mutate(rankSentenceLength = rank(sentenceLength, ties.method='first')) %>% 
  filter(rankSentenceLength== 1) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  
   #filter the most common path for the same agent/target
  group_by(IO_Agent, IO_Target) %>%
  mutate(rankNumberReference = rank(desc(Number_Reference), ties.method='first')) %>%
  filter(rankNumberReference<=3) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # Arrange
  arrange(desc(Number_Reference_Total), desc(Number_Reference)) %>%
  # Create Composite Label with path and frequency
  mutate(label_composite = paste0(IO_Agent, 
                                  " --> ", 
                                  IO_Target, 
                                  " (", 
                                  Number_Reference_Total, 
                                  ")"
                                  )) %>%
  group_by(label_composite) %>%
  select(Path_Short, Number_Reference, Sentence) %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = paste0("Most Common Ties with ", IO, " as source")
  )  %>%
  cols_label(
    Path_Short = "Path",
    Number_Reference = "N. References",
    Sentence = "Example"
  ) %>%
  cols_align(
    align = "center",
    columns = everything()
    )
